name: electricity production, hydro, pumped storage | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21131/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kWh of electricity in pumped storage power plants in Argentina in 2014. ;The physical information about the different power plants is obtained from the Argentinean energy statistics. ;The emissions data are taken over from the "electricity production, hydro, pumped storage/GLO, 2008 dataset" (accessed: January 24th, 2018).  

From water pumped up from a lower to an upper reservoir.

The activity ends with 1 kWh of high voltage electricity produced at the power plant and arrived at the busbar.

The dataset includes the use of pump energy (electricity, high voltage), lubricant oil, the volume of the reservoir, the mass of water passing through the turbines and an estimation of greenhouse gas emissions out of the water reservoir. 

The dataset doesn't include an analysis of net greenhouse gas emissions (due to a lack of respective information) and the hydrological and biological impacts are only rudimentary included via land use (occupation and transformation) data.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The Annual Production Volume is valid for the year 2014
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data represent the average of a characteristic sample of Swiss reservoir hydropower plants, valid for pumped storage hydro power plants.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Definition of pumped storage in this dataset: The water is not being pumped for circulation reasons, but for increasing the inflow of a reservoir. Net production is the gross production minus about 1% losses. Additionally there is energy needed for pumping. The efficiency of a pumped storage hydropower plant is around 70% (p.14 in Bauer et al. 2007)
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
This dataset is based on the "electricity production, hydro, pumped storage/GLO 2008" and adapted for Argentina (accessed: January 24th, 2018). All data have been taken from statistics from the pumped storage hydro power plants operating in Argentina, except the following which have been adapted for Argentina based on the original dataset due to lack of local data:
Dinitrogen monoxide emissions have been calculated based on the electricity production volume in mountainous and non mountainous regions in Argentina and the emission factors for alpine and non alpine regions taken from the original dataset.  Carbon dioxide, from soil or biomass stock and Methane, non-foss have been taken from Scherer and Pfister (2017). The amount of lubricating oil per kWh and of "electricity, high voltage from Technosphere" have been taken from the original dataset.
Scherer, Laura; Pfister, Stephan (2017), National Carbon and Water Footprints of Hydropower, Mendeley Data, v1 http://dx.doi.org/10.17632/xdgszz76vz.1#file-032818b9-a767-4e16-a207-1fb0db2c9a35
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Sampling procedure 
There are only two pumped storage hydro power plants: Los Reyunos, located in a monainous region, and Río Grande, located in a non-mountainaeous area. Both have been considered in this dataset. The representativeness is therefore 100 %

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The specific turbine water amount is inversely proportional to the average  head. A guidance value says that a hydropower plant can produce 1kWh of electricity with 1 m3 water over a head of 450 m. The ecological relevance of the turbine water amount is that it presents a demonstrative dimension of water being taken from natural water balance for a while

flow.name: Water, turbine use, unspecified natural origin

exchanges.description:
Calculated value
The original state before setting up the reservoir has to be classified as module 'transformation, from unspecified' due to the fact that various types of flooded ground can be distinguished. 
This exchange amount is taken over from datasets for both alpine and non-alpine power plants. The water surface of all pumped storage power plants with pondage in both mountain and no mountain regions have been summed up. Source: Inventario de Presas y Centrales Hidroeléctricas de la República Argentina,- 1a ed. Subsecretaria de Recursos Hídricos de la Nación
Buenos Aires : Ministerio de Planificación Federal, Inversión Pública y Servicios, 2010. 
ISBN 978-987-23585-8-7
Calculated value based on literature values
Literature value/calculated value. The needed amount of infrastructure per kWh produced is calculated with the lifetime and the annual net energy production.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. This exchange amount is calculated as the difference between the transformed area and the area occupied by the infrastrature of the power plant.

Calculated value. 
Estimation. The useful volume of all pumped storage hydro power plants have been considered, and related to the amount of electricy produced during the useful life.
Source: Inventario de Presas y Centrales Hidroeléctricas de la República Argentina,- 1a ed. Subsecretaria de Recursos Hídricos de la Nación
Buenos Aires : Ministerio de Planificación Federal, Inversión Pública y Servicios, 2010. ISBN 978-987-23585-8-7

The usable capacity of reservoirs is an important figure both for significant water supply regions and for the definition of ecological relevant indices. First of all the usable capacity is a measurement for the rearrangement of the runoff regime over time, i.e. the amount of water detracted temporarily from the natural water cycle and returned to the surface waters with delay. Depending on the type of reservoir (daily, monthly, annual reservoir) the delay takes less or more time. Second, the usable capacity of reservoirs is a measurement for the occupied volume of reservoirs. Thereby, the volume of the fluctuation area is considered, i.e. not the total reservoir volume.
"The global value is calculated as production weighted average of all pumped storage alpine and non-alpine reservoirs in ev3.2.

exchanges.description: Estimation. The area for the barrage and the power station are assumed to amount to 1% of the total land use. No land use for access roads was taken into account.
Estimation. The lubricating oil is in a closed loop system (i.e. cannot get into the turbined water system) and is disposed annualy as waste oil in a hazardous waste treatment plant.

exchanges.description: Estimation. This exchange has been taken over from a dataset for a Swiss reservoir power plant without pumping. For the consumption of lubricating oil during plant operation no data was available. It is assumed that both turbines and run-of-river plants need the same amount of oil hence the information about lubricating oil consumption of run-of-rivers is adopted. A consumption of lubricating oil for turbines of 9 liters per GWh is estimated. With an oil density of 0.84 kg/l this amounts to 0.007 g/kWh. The lubricating oil is in a closed loop system (i.e. cannot get into the turbined water system) and is disposed annualy as waste oil in a hazardous waste treatment plant.
